subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etyl}}
{{Han compound|å¤§|t1=man|å£|t2=mouth, object|ls=ic}}. Top figure simplified to {{zh-l|*åœŸ}}, unrelated to {{zh-l|*å£«|scholar, gentleman}}, while bottom simplified to {{zh-l|*å¶}}. There are various interpretations of the combination of â€œmanâ€ and â€œmouth, objectâ€. One is that the ideograph represented a man with a hole marked in his crotch, and the inventors of writing had perhaps â€œanusâ€ (i.e. getting rid of) in mind ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}). Another is that it represented a man '''departing''' from a cave or city.

Alternatively, it may be the original character of {{och-l|å‘¿|to open one's mouth}}, the meaning given by the combination of {{zh-l|*å¤§|big}} and {{zh-l|*å£|mouth}}. The meaning â€œto departâ€ would be an extension of the meaning â€œto open one's mouthâ€, as the lips '''depart''' from each other when one's mouth is open.

{{w|Shuowen Jiezi}} interprets the character as a {{Han compound|å¤§|ğ ™´|t1=man|c1=s|c2=p|ls=psc|nocap=1}}.

In addition, {{lang|zh|å»}} is also the original character of {{och-l|ç›|to cover}}. The {{zh-l|*å¤§}} is a cover on top of an object {{zh-l|*å£}}.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
There were two pronunciations in Middle Chinese. The rising tone pronunciation originally meant â€œto put away, to eliminateâ€ (causative of â€œto go awayâ€), and the falling tone â€œto go away, to leave, to departâ€ (anticausative). The merger of the two pronunciations already happened in Old Chinese and most extant dialects do not observe this distinction now.

This word is of Sino-Tibetan origin with the basic meaning of "to get rid of". Compare {{cog|bo|à½¦à¾à¾±à½‚||to spend, to lay out; dung, excrement}}, {{m|bo|à½¢à¾à¾±à½‚||dirt, excrement}}, {{cog|my|á€€á€»||to fall, to become low}}, {{m|my|á€á€»||to put down, to bring down, to lower}}.
